smell_analysis.justification: No empty diagrams were found; all pages that clearly show a UML diagram (use-case, class/database, activity, state, or package) contain at least one central element such as a class, table, use case, activity, or state node.

In the main use case diagram 'Kaupade funktsionaalne allsüsteem' on page 3 every visual use case oval is connected by at least one association line to one or more actors (Kaupade haldur, Klient, Juhataja, Kaupade vaataja, Uudistaja, or Süsteem), so there is no use case without an actor.

The use cases on the diagram 'Kaupade funktsionaalne allsüsteem' all describe distinct activities (for example 'Aktiveeri kaup', 'Lõpeta kaup', 'Registreeri kaup', 'Muuda kaup mittaktiivseks'), and no pair of use cases clearly describes the same activity while being associated with the same actor set.

The package diagram 'Kauba FASiga seotud pädevusalad ja registrid' shows packages such as 'Kaupade register', 'Isikute register', and 'Kaupade funktsionaalne allsüsteem', and within each package the listed model elements have unique primary names (for example within 'Kaupade register': Kauba_kategooria_omamine, Kauba_variant, Kaup, Kauba elutsüklid), so no package contains multiple elements with the same primary name.

Across the database and transformed class diagrams, repeated data values such as keys (isik_id, kauba_kood, riik_kood and similar) are always connected between tables via explicit foreign key relationships, and there is no clear case where the same real-world data is stored redundantly in two tables without a foreign key between them.

All use case names and the related function list in 'Kaupade funktsionaalne allsüsteem' consistently start with an active verb in Estonian, such as 'Aktiveeri kaup', 'Lõpeta kaup', 'Vaata kõiki kaupasid', 'Registreeri hävinud kaup' and 'Unusta kaup', so there is no inconsistent naming form among use cases.

In the state diagram 'Kauba seisundidiagramm' the states Ootel, Aktiivne, Mitteaktiivne, Lõpetatud and Unustatud all have at least one incoming transition from either the initial state or another state (for example transitions from Ootel and Aktiivne to Lõpetatud and Unustatud), so every state is reachable.

In both activity diagrams ('Kauba lõpetamise tegevusdiagramm' and 'Kauba aktiveerimise tegevusdiagramm') every action node such as 'Vaata kõiki kaupasid, mida saab lõpetada', 'Otsi kaupa', 'Vali kaup', 'Lõpeta valitud kaup' and 'Aktiveeri valitud kaup' is connected into the control flow from the initial node and eventually leads toward a final node, with no isolated or unreachable actions.

All relationships between classes and tables in the conceptual and transformed register diagrams show multiplicity information (such as 0..*, 1, 0..1) or are drawn using standard crow's-foot or foreign key notation typical for database diagrams, so there is no association that lacks multiplicity indicators at both ends.

The class diagram 'Kaupade register_suur' on page 2 contains well over ten central elements, including at least Kaup, Kauba_kategooria_omamine, Kauba_variant, Kauba_tootja, Kauba_seisundi_liik, Kauba_kategooria, Kauba_kategooria_tüüp, Töötaja, Töötaja_roll, Töötaja_seisundi_liik, Isik, Kasutajakonto, Klient and several classifier types, so the total number of classes/tables clearly exceeds the threshold of ten.

In diagrams such as 'Kaupade register_suur' and the more compact 'Kaupade register', the central class Kaup has relationship lines to multiple surrounding classes including Kauba_kategooria_omamine, Kauba_seisundi_liik, Kauba_tootja, Kauba_variant and at least two separate associations to Töötaja (for the roles 'registreerija' and 'viimane muutja'), giving six or more distinct visible connectors touching this single class within one diagram.

Across the examined diagrams, related elements (for example Kaup and its associated classifier tables, or activity steps and decisions) are placed at roughly similar distances, and no relationship line is noticeably more than twice the average element spacing on its diagram, so no excessive distance between related elements is clearly visible.

Every use case name (such as 'Aktiveeri kaup', 'Unusta kaup', 'Vaata aktiivseid kaupasid') and each activity action label (for example 'Vaata kõiki kaupasid, mida saab lõpetada', 'Otsi kaupa', 'Vali kaup', 'Aktiveeri valitud kaup') begins with an imperative verb in Estonian, while non-verb phrases starting with 'Kas' are used on decision nodes rather than on action nodes, so no use case or activity action name violates this rule.

No class, table, attribute/column or use case is named with three or fewer characters alone; short sequences such as 'id' only appear as parts of longer identifiers like 'isik_id' and state names like 'Alg' apply to states rather than classes, tables, attributes or use cases.

Entity class and table names such as Isik, Klient, Kaup, Kauba_variant, Kauba_kategooria and Varv all start with uppercase letters and are singular; plural forms like 'Isikute register' or 'Kaupade register' label register groupings rather than individual entity tables and are excluded by the interpretation rules.

Attribute and column names in both the conceptual and transformed diagrams consistently begin with lowercase letters, for example e_mail, isikukood, kauba_kood, nimetus, on_aktiivne, soetusmaksumus and myygihind_km_ta, while uppercase markers like 'PK_' and 'FK_' are used only in separate key or index identifiers, not as the first character of attribute names.

Database tables corresponding to domain entities (Isik, Klient, Kaup, Kauba_kategooria, Kauba_kategooria_tyyp, Kauba_seisundi_liik, Varv, Tootaja and others) are named in singular form, whereas plural wording occurs only in the names of register overviews like 'Isikute register', which do not represent individual entity tables for the purposes of this rule.

No class, table or attribute name uses a type-indicating prefix such as 'tbl_', 'uc_' or 'str'; the only technical prefixes observed (PK_, FK_, pfK_, IXFK_ and similar) appear in key and index identifiers like 'PK_Kaup' or 'FK_Kaup_Kauba_tootja', which are explicitly allowed and are not the primary names of classes, tables or attributes.
